My wife signed us up for the Child Advocates Run this pass weekend. I was set to do the 5k at 8 am Saturday morning. On the way there, we got caught up in traffic and ended up arriving 3mins into the 5k run. At first I thought, I missed it. There's no sense of me doing it now but then I looked at my wife and daughter and asked myself, what kind of example am I making for them. So, I take off and go as hard as I can. As I ran, I kept telling myself, "lead by example and FINISH". I ended up running the 5k in 20mins and winning 1st place in my age group. My girls were the first I seen at the finish line. Your WHY for doing things has to be bigger than you. Think about who you are doing it for and FINISH what you start!

Parenting —> One of the Hardest Things you’ll EVER do. We always hear about how great it is and see how awesome it looks on Social Media but no one ever really seems to keep it 💯. Truth is that this thing is difficult, especially if you are trying to do it right. Don’t be fooled! It’s WORTH it if you WORK for it. And Working at it is a daily thing. I may look like I have it all under control but I struggle all the time and I make mistakes everyday. We need to understand that. It is my willingness to want to be better that gets me through it. I am NOWHERE near being perfect but I am for DAMN SURE always persistent! It’s the process of learning and growing that we must focus on as parents. Learn to love the process and you’ll appreciate the journey. Shoutout to all my parents and soon to be parents out there! I SEE YOU! Keep Pushing, Keep Learning, Keep Growing! I’m with you!

In 2011, I was asked to speak at my Kente Ceremony for my college graduation. It was the first time I had ever spoken to such a big crowd. I was prepared, nervous and scared before I went up but realized a second into speaking that it was easy. It seemed effortless and felt natural. I mean, people cried, laughed and cheered harder than I have ever seen. I told myself right after I spoke- “This is what I want to do”. I didn’t notice it back then but that experience was what they call “BEGINNERS LUCK”. It’s the experience that pulls you in and allows you to see your potential. I recognized this to be true from every speaking engagement I did after that one. Each one seemed harder to do. More effort was required to prepare for each engagement. To this day I have to work at my presentations no matter how big or small they are. My dream became to Impact lives through my speaking but before every dream is realized, life challenges you to show how bad you really want it. The journey is what prepares you to MASTER your work! And I am on the mission to conquer my field! Let’s Work!

When I asked the question “what is vulnerability?” One of my male students responded with- “weakness”. I stopped and asked him why. He told me that being vulnerable is letting people in and that is how you get hurt. I thanked him for his honesty and then explained that vulnerability is opening yourself up and exposing yourself. Now that can lead you to getting hurt but it can also free you. It’s all in how you perceive it and use the experience. Being in touch with your feelings and speaking your truth is hard to do and therefore you need strength to do it. When you are true to yourself and accept truth, it is easier to be true with the world. It won’t be easy and not everyone will accept you at first but if you stand firm, they will respect you! The story of how she taught me to be an ALPHA- It was a regular school day as we (4 of my 3rd grade friends and I) sat in the cafeteria finishing our breakfast and waiting to be called for morning recess outside. I remember it being cold but nothing too crazy that will keep us inside. As time went along, we noticed students leaving but no one was being directed to head through the doors that led to the playground outside. “Let’s go before we run out of time,” yelled my friend that was soon to be nine. Now, I couldn’t lie, I felt something wrong, but I didn’t speak up and just followed along. There was no one there but us as we ran and played tag for about an hour long plus. Then we heard someone shout, “WHAT THE HELL ARE YOU DOING?” as we ran all about. We look up and see the scariest dean of the school, looking at us like a bunch of young fools. As we get close she notices me and yells out, “You’re Mrs. Rosado’s son, right? Oh, just wait ‘til she sees and hears this.” Boy was I scared. My mom was a beast and all the students knew this. As we walked up the stairs in a single file line, the dean noticed my fear and said, “You know you mama don’t play, so why would you stay?” I looked up at her but had nothing to say. We get to the door and I start to just pray, “God I think today is the day.” My mom then walks out of her class with real concern on her face and then turns to the dean to ask what just took place. Well, when she hears the whole case, she yells aloud, “WHAT” and gets all in my space. She then grabs a hold of my ear and turns it so dear. I yell, and I scream but I could not hold back a tear. My mom then gets close to that ear and states, “Don’t you ever follow the crowd, you stay in front of the line. Are we clear?” Yes Ma, till this day, we are clear as day and I still lead my way.

We are all born with the young foolish mind. Unaware of fear, limits and barriers which hold us back in our older years. It is the learned behaviors from our experiences that slows us down. I see this more clearly now as a father. When I’m running around and playing with my daughter, I always try to get her off guard and scare her. I try to see what she made of, you know. She chases me as I run towards the room to shut off all the light and hid behind the door. As she enters the room, she looks around to scan the premises and slowly searches for her pray. I wait as she walks around determined to find her punk daddy. Once she’s completely away from the door, I shut it closed then jump at her like, AHHHHHHHH. It goes silent, she then grabs my face, laughs like hell, opens the door and walk out. I have tried to get her several times in different situations and in all different rooms (bedrooms, bathrooms, living room and even closets). I even scared myself sometimes trying to get her. I’ve concluded that, my baby is a thug! You see she doesn’t know what to be scared of or why to be scared of it. We are all born this way. It’s the energy and vibe that is around us that give us fear in our experiences. To my daughter, daddy jumping out at her in the dark is fun playtime because we both laugh in the dark. First step to overcoming fear is to recognize what actually happened to us young so that we can face it and move one.

It’s not about how you start that makes you successful. It’s more about pushing yourself to start that makes the difference. This is a picture of me and my daughter at my first ever professional speaking engagement. It was about two years ago when I started speaking and I was terrified. Family and old friends were in the crowd along with a bunch of faces that I have never seen before. All eyes were on me and just like anyone else, I doubted myself. I prepared for months but it was different the moment I stepped in front of the crowd. I started a little shaky but as time went along I felt more and more comfortable. I realized that once I got over the fear of starting, my preparation kicked in and I knew my stuff. From that experience I was able to find the courage to continue to speak and now I enjoy the that same feeling of doubt right before I start. It currently drives and motivates me to get my performances done. But I always remember where I started from. Like NIKE, JUST DO IT and see what happens. Bad or good, you’ll always appreciate your beginning stages!

My daughter came down with a fever yesterday. She was out of it all morning then somewhere around noon, she got up and asked me if we could go to the gym. She goes in and gets right to it. I laugh and watch this cute 3 year old really go to work. She goes for about 15 mins and when she was done, I ask her why she wanted to go to the gym and she says, “Because I want to be like you and mommy”. Wow! If that couldn’t get me up this morning, I don’t know what would. Lead and give them an example to follow.

Translating Your Success is available NOW on Amazon. Here's the book description- "Translating Your Success has a special meaning to Carlos J. Malave, who grew up in a bilingual household, hearing Spanish from his father and English from his mother. He learned at an early age that two different words could have the same meaning.
As a child, he was a success at sports but lagged behind his siblings in academics. After reflecting on his circumstances, Carlos realized that he could succeed in school by applying the same principles that made him a good athlete to being a good student. He translated his success from one area of his life to another. And, as he grew older, he applied these same principles to his life. His father had a drinking problem, and Carlos had often asked him, "Why don't you stop drinking?" But he never asked him, "Why do you drink?" To solve a problem, one first must determine its cause.

This approach is the basis of the three-step Malave method: becoming "consciously fit," turning happiness into a mind-set, and learning to possess motivation. In each chapter, the author provides exercises that lead to the self-awareness necessary to set your long-term goals and to translate today's successes into a joyful life."

Completing my first book gave me the confidence to believe that I could read more. As a teacher at my school I realized that the same thing I went through as a child was going on with my students. They had no interest in the books they were reading and or they felt they couldn't read the books that were presented to them. This is where I got the inspiration to write my own book. "Translating Your Success" was inspired and written for all students in need of a reading boost. In only 100 pages (12 chapters), I tell stories that get to the point, give the lessons that were learned from the stories and ask you questions of your own story for reflection.
